The instruments on the Voyager 1 spacecraft, like most other spacecraft, are given instructions by scientists and engineers on the ground.

The process of sending instructions to a spacecraft is called "uplinking." Scientists and engineers at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California, prepare a set of instructions for the spacecraft based on its current location, orientation, and mission objectives.

These instructions are then transmitted to the spacecraft through NASA's Deep Space Network (DSN), which is a network of large radio antennas located in California, Spain, and Australia. The DSN antennas send a signal to the spacecraft, which receives the instructions and executes them.

The process of sending instructions to a spacecraft is complex, as it involves accounting for the time delay in the communication signal due to the vast distances involved. For example, it takes over 20 hours for a signal to travel to Voyager 1 and back, due to the large distance between the spacecraft and Earth. This means that any instructions sent to Voyager 1 will take at least 20 hours to reach the spacecraft, and any data or images sent back by the spacecraft will take at least 20 hours to reach Earth.

Despite these challenges, scientists and engineers on the Voyager mission have been able to communicate with the spacecraft and keep it operational for over 44 years, a testament to their skill and dedication.
